definition: to transmit/to lead/to guide/to conduct/to direct

sentences.english: The pity of it is that an intelligent man appears to have been seduced by the sound of his own voice.
sentences.chinese: 不幸的是，这位智者似乎被自己的声音误导了。

sentences.english: Nay, worse, for it often misleads.
sentences.chinese: 不，更坏的，它通常误导人。

sentences.english: The whole meeting was an elaborately staged act of misdirection.
sentences.chinese: 整个会面就是一场精心安排的误导破案的表演。

sentences.english: To talk or act insincerely or misleadingly; equivocate.
sentences.chinese: 不忠实地或误导地说或做。

sentences.english: The misleader let me use the lead instead of the unsteady metal.
sentences.chinese: 误导者让我用铅代替了不稳定的铁。

sentences.english: As all bankers know, league tables can mislead.
sentences.chinese: 所有的银行家都知道，排行榜有误导作用。

sentences.english: Don't be misleaded by the Caption; it is untrue.
sentences.chinese: 标题并不真实，不要被标题误导。

sentences.english: Likewise, visuals can lead to erroneous ideas about the triune God.
sentences.chinese: 同样地，图像会误导人对三一真神持错误观念。

sentences.english: But passion is an emotion that blinds you.
sentences.chinese: 但是，激情却会遮住你的慧眼，误导你的判断。

sentences.english: Now I have just realized I mislead you in something.
sentences.chinese: 我现在意识到我有点误导你们了。

sentences.english: Further, the poor are not as poor as government statistics intentionally misrepresent.
sentences.chinese: 而且，穷人并没有政府统计资料所误导的那么贫穷。

sentences.english: The official has since been punished for "misleading" Yang and her husband.
sentences.chinese: 后来该官员由于“误导”杨水英和她丈夫而受到处罚。

sentences.english: Don't misguide the people from the real threat.
sentences.chinese: 不要试图误导群众让他们忽略真实的威胁。

sentences.english: 3 to avoid any error that might lead to the wring and prejudicial decisions in the future.
sentences.chinese: 存货盘点可避免任何会对未来决策评估之误导。

sentences.english: We were misled and became slaves to many lusts and pleasures.
sentences.chinese: 我们被误导而成为罪的奴隶。

sentences.english: Well, even the best data can be subtly misleading.
sentences.chinese: 其实，即使最好的资料数据也可以巧妙的误导你。

definition: to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
variant of 矇騙|蒙骗[meng1 pian4]
to obscure/to confuse/to mix up/to blur/to mislead
to make a fool out of/to fool/to dupe
to falsely believe/to be mislead/to fall for (a trick etc)
to rock/to sway/to flicker (e.g. of lights reflected on water)/to flutter (e.g. of a flag)/to trick sb into doing sth/to dupe/to con
selective listening/to hear what one wants to hear
to spread falsehoods/to increasingly distort the truth/to pile errors on top of errors (idiom)
